body:
libvterm v0.3 supports reflow of terminal buffer when Nvim is resized
Since v0.3 is now a required dependency, enable it by default to find
(and fix) possible issues.

Note: Neovim's scrollback buffer does not support reflow (yet), so lines
vanishing into the buffer due to a too small window will be restored
without reflow.

Interesting that it stopped failing on CI, though.

@leonerd the crash is in `libvterm`:
```
resize_buffer (screen=screen@entry=0x60d000000ee0, bufidx=bufidx@entry=1, new_rows=new_rows@entry=1, new_cols=new_cols@entry=12, active=52, statefields=statefields@entry=0x7fffffff9c78) at src/screen.c:654
```
I'll see if I can play with the test file to get minimal reproducing steps.
Just reduce `:terminal` window width to 1, then reduce its height.
I'll keep an eye out for a test case then

```vim
:10new
:20vnew
:terminal nvim --clean
:vertical resize -19
:resize -9
```
Yep, that triggers the SIGABRT. But the CI passed, strange.

To be precise, what's happening here is that we trigger the assert in
https://bazaar.launchpad.net/~libvterm/libvterm/trunk/view/head:/src/screen.c#L655

This also affects Vim, but they just patched out the check in their vendored `libvterm`:
https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/67578e5bcf7404d40d42876b738b72e68add1a3e

As far as I can tell, this issue is specific to resizing nested Nvim instances (related to cursor handling), so not exactly a common scenario.

Not sure what the best way to proceed here is. We could simply relax the test (resize to more than one column)?

@leonerd This is a crashing test case for libvterm 0.3.1 : https://gist.github.com/bfredl/77071561e06ad2e3b08ad43418c5a8ac

I tried to trace out all essential nvim calls into libvterm, hopefully this is representative enough
First observation: None of data1, data2, data3 or data5 are needed at all. Same crash in same way with only data4 in place.

(The trunk tarball on launchpad is not useable since it 1. has a different directory layout and 2. doesn't include the `src/encoding/*.inc` files and 3. doesn't work right even after fixing these things manually.)

(Now I remember: 2. those files are generated via `tbl2inc.pl`, which we removed from the tarball: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21986; the generated files are included in the release tarballs but not the trunk tarballs.)

This is cool, though seems incomplete. Text is not always restored after widening the window again. Easy way to notice this is to do multiple vertical-splits. Steps:

```
:terminal
cat README.md
:vsplit
:vsplit
:vsplit
:vsplit
:vsplit
:only
```
Yes, don't you remember the discussion above about scrollback not reflowing?

oh, that discussion was before the libvterm fixes. I guess I got confused by the news.txt : 

> Lines that are not visible and kept in |'scrollback'| are not reflown.

I thought it was saying "lines _not kept in scrollback_" are not reflowed. The conjunction is ambiguous :)

Ah, I see. No, the libvterm fix was only for the (deterministic) abort; scrollback is on our side and not influenced by that.

(Lines that are not visible and not kept in scrollback are just plain gone, so there's nothing to reflow ;))

I have the issue that the vim terminal still inserts linebreaks (`\n` characters) at the window edge.
No matter what I did, following every piece of advice here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2280030/how-to-stop-line-breaking-in-vim

In this reddit thread, people also reason that this PR does not fix this issue, unfortunately: https://old.reddit.com/r/neovim/comments/1dak3rw/longs_lines_in_terminal_are_copied_with_newlines/

Nothing worked, so I am concluding that this is a (Neo)vim limitation or bug?
It would be great if there was an easy setting to prevent the Vim terminal to insert newlines into the terminal output, because this is a huge problem when e.g. I get a big blog of a JSON response back from some API call and want to yank/paste that somewhere else, as it's full of `\n` characters that I would have manually clean up.

I can not resort to using Tmux as I am on Windows (at least most of the time), and I would really love to use full Vim in the terminal.
Yes, softwrapping of terminal lines is a different thing and not implemented (yet).
